draw a histogram of class by male and female, use colors

To create a visual representation of how different classes of people are distributed by gender, I started by gathering the necessary information about the individuals in our dataset. This included their class (like Crew, 1st, or 2nd), gender (Male or Female), and other details.

Next, I organized this information to count how many males and females belong to each class. This counting helps us understand the distribution of genders within each class.

Then, I decided to use a bar chart to display this information clearly. In the chart, each class is represented on the horizontal axis, while the vertical axis shows the number of individuals. I used different colors to distinguish between males and females, making it easy to see the differences at a glance.

Finally, I added labels and a title to the chart to ensure that anyone looking at it could easily understand what it represents. After creating the chart, I saved it as an image file so it could be shared or viewed later.

draw a histogram of class by male and female, use colors, i want the columns next to each other

To create a visual representation of how many males and females are in each class, I first gathered the necessary information about the classes and the genders of the individuals. 

I organized this data into a format that allows us to easily compare the counts of males and females for each class. Then, I created a bar chart where each class has two bars next to each other—one representing females and the other representing males. 

To make the chart visually appealing and easy to understand, I chose distinct colors for each gender: blue for males and pink for females. I also added labels to the chart to clarify what it represents, including a title and labels for the axes. Finally, I saved the chart as an image file so it can be shared or viewed later. 

This way, anyone looking at the chart can quickly see the distribution of males and females across different classes.
